reviewText:
Prova d'orchestra (Federico Fellini, 1978, 70')

Produced by Michael Fengler and Renzo Rossellini. Story by Federico Fellini. Written and screenplay Federico Fellini and Brunello Rondi. Starring Balduin Baas. Music by Nino Rota. Cinematography by Giuseppe Rotunno. Editing by Ruggero Mastroianni.

Among its many national traits, the Italian cinema had accepted music early with some more respect than notably Hollywood had done, where music was long simply used for emphasis of picture and story in a most direct emotive way. As early as with Giuseppe De Santis' Riso amaro (1948), Goffredo Petrassi, a leading Italian composer of modern classical music, conductor, and teacher, was asked for film music. Petrassi (1904-2003) is today still considered as one of the most influential modern Italian composers of the twentieth century. Two even better known names followed: Nino Rota, associated with Fellini's work (today's example), and Ennio Morricone, known mostly for his music to Italo-Westerns, and there perhaps most for his harmonica motif in C'era una volta il West (1968).

Orchestra Rehearsal follows an Italian orchestra as the members go on a noisy graffiti style strike against the conductor, played by (German actor) Balduin Baas. The film was shown out of competition at the 1979 Cannes Film Festival. Considered by some to be underrated, Orchestra Rehearsal was the last collaboration between composer Nino Rota and Fellini, due to Rota's death in 1979. A Pirandello/Ionesco type atmosphere: The message is not exactly clear - music, in a time of terror (the rehearsal building also gets struck by an earthquake and/or a metal destruction globe), as an antibody? One violinist says to the audience: You should hear the music the way we hear it when playing.

Do they know more? Whatever the final answers are, Fellini/Rota keep us entertained and guessing, the orchestra some Dantean institution ...

181us - Prova d'orchestra (Federico Fellini, 1978, 70') -What was that? - 27/9/2012
